title: 111_s1065
content: The "Iran Sanctions Enabling Act of 2009" allows for disassociation from companies supporting Iran's nuclear weapons efforts due to moral, prudential, or reputational concerns. Policymakers and fund managers may divest from companies operating in sanctioned countries or having relationships with prohibited entities. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "energy sector" refers to activities related to developing petroleum, natural gas resources, or nuclear power. The term "financial institution" is defined as in the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996. "Iran" includes any agency or instrumentality of Iran. The term "person" encompasses natural persons, corporations, governmental entities, and multilateral development institutions. The term "State" includes several states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other territories. The term "State or local government" encompasses state agencies, local governments, and other governmental bodies. The term "State" includes various states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other territories. The term "State or local government" refers to state agencies, local governments, and other governmental bodies. Additionally, it includes any public institution of higher education as defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. State and local governments have the authority to divest from companies invested in Iran's energy sector. The United States supports State and local governments' decision to divest from persons with investments of $20,000,000 or more in Iran's energy sector. State and local governments can enforce measures to divest from or prohibit investment in such persons. Investment activities in Iran with a value of $20,000,000 or more in the energy sector or related industries are subject to restrictions. Financial institutions extending credit for investments in Iran's energy sector must meet specific requirements. State and local governments must provide written notice to affected parties regarding divestment measures. State and local governments must provide written notice to affected parties regarding divestment measures. The measure shall apply not earlier than 90 days after receiving the notice. Each person has the opportunity to demonstrate they do not engage in investment activities in Iran, and if proven, the measure will not apply to them. In subsection (c), the measure does not apply to the person. Congress advises against mistakenly targeting individuals with measures under subsection (b) unless efforts are made to verify their investment activities in Iran. State or local governments must notify the Attorney General within 30 days of adopting a measure under subsection (b). Measures authorized under subsection (b) are not preempted by Federal laws. In this section, "investment" of assets for State or local governments includes commitments, loans, and contracts for goods or services. "Assets" refer to public monies, pension funds, and similar instruments controlled by the government, excluding employee benefit plans covered by a specific act. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 applies to measures adopted by State or local governments before, on, or after the enactment of the Act, with notice requirements for measures adopted after the enactment date. SEC. 5. Safe harbor for changes of investment policies by asset managers, allowing investment activities in Iran as described in the Iran Sanctions Enabling Act of 2009. SEC. 6. Safe harbor for changes of investment policies by employee benefit plans. SEC. 6. Safe harbor for changes of investment policies by employee benefit plans, allowing divesting or avoiding investing in entities engaged in Iran-related activities described in the Iran Sanctions Enabling Act of 2009. The Act will end 30 days after the President certifies that Iran no longer supports terrorism, as defined by various laws. The Government of Iran must cease support for international terrorism and halt the pursuit of weapons and missile technology.
